text: The inner membrane, cell wall, and outer membrane constitute the Gramnegative cell envelope.
Another common external structure is the flagellum (plural, flagella), a helical protein filament whose rotary motor propels the cell in search of a more such as Bacteroides and Prevotella species.
The nitrogen-fixing symbiont Sinorhizobium has cell-surface proteins that help the bacteria to colonize legume plants for nitrogen fixation.
The wall material is flexible, but it limits expansion of the cytoplasm, keeping the cell membrane intact when water flows in.
In a Gram-negative bacterium, the cell wall lies within the periplasm, a water-filled space containing nutrientbinding proteins and secretion machines.
Between the inner and outer membranes lies the cell wall, a fortress-like structure composed of sugar chains linked covalently by peptides (peptidoglycan).
But to visualize the cell’s interior as a whole requires higher resolution, as in electron microscopy.
The bacterial envelope includes cell-surface proteins that bacterium colonize the human intestinal epithelium.

This membrane prevents cytoplasmic proteins from leaking out and maintains gradients of ions and nutrients.
